revision_content.description: Learn how to collect, organize, present, interpret, and analyze data using various tools like graphs, charts, and statistical methods.

subtopics.title: Data Collection
subtopics.definition: The process of gathering information or facts for analysis.

example.question: Give one method of collecting data.

subtopics.whyItMatters: All decisions in research and planning start with good data.
quickTips: Use clear and unbiased questions.
Always record data accurately.

subtopics.title: Types of Data
subtopics.definition: Data can be qualitative (descriptive) or quantitative (numerical).
subtopics.whyItMatters: Different types need different ways of organizing and displaying.
quickTips: Discrete = Counted (like students), Continuous = Measured (like height)
Know your data type before analysis.

subtopics.title: Frequency Tables
subtopics.definition: A table that shows how often each value in a data set occurs.

example.question: If 5 students scored 10 marks, whatâ€™s the frequency of 10?

subtopics.whyItMatters: Helps organize raw data for easier interpretation.
quickTips: Use tally marks for easier counting.
Include totals at the bottom.

subtopics.title: Bar Graphs
subtopics.definition: A chart that uses bars to represent data values visually.

example.question: What do we label on the x-axis in a bar graph?

subtopics.whyItMatters: Bar graphs make comparisons between categories very clear.
quickTips: Bars should be equal width, spaced equally.
Y-axis always has the numbers (frequency).

subtopics.title: Line Graphs
subtopics.definition: A graph that uses points connected by lines to show changes over time.

example.question: When is a line graph most useful?

subtopics.whyItMatters: Used in weather, finance, growth tracking, etc.
quickTips: Always connect the dots in order.
Use a title and label axes clearly.

subtopics.title: Pie Charts
subtopics.definition: A circular chart divided into sectors showing proportions.

example.question: What angle represents 25% in a pie chart?

subtopics.whyItMatters: Pie charts help in showing parts of a whole clearly.
quickTips: Total angles must equal 360Â°.
Convert data to percentages or fractions first.

subtopics.title: Mean (Average)
subtopics.definition: The total sum of values divided by the number of values.
subtopics.whyItMatters: A quick summary of overall data performance.
quickTips: Always add all data values before dividing.
Use mean to compare sets of data.

subtopics.title: Median
subtopics.definition: The middle value when data is arranged in order.
subtopics.whyItMatters: Gives the center of the data, unaffected by outliers.
quickTips: If even number of items, average the two middle ones.
Always sort data before finding median.

subtopics.title: Mode
subtopics.definition: The value that appears most frequently in a data set.
subtopics.whyItMatters: Useful when you want the most popular or common item.
quickTips: There can be more than one mode.
If no value repeats, thereâ€™s no mode.

subtopics.title: Range
subtopics.definition: The difference between the highest and lowest values.
subtopics.whyItMatters: Shows how spread out the data is.
quickTips: Check for any extreme values.
Range helps in identifying variability.
